guide.description: A guide for users of Channels

item.description:
Channels is an online collaboration planning service.
It enables * analysts to build plans for information sharing-enabled collaboration, * communities of organizations to adopt and participate in these plans, * user to get collaboration checklists derived from participation in these communities, * and administrators to manage the Channels service.

You can * change the spelling of your name, * edit the email address Channels will use to communicate with you * upload a photo of yourself
Make sure you press the Apply button for the changes to take effect.

This allows you to provide different ways for your collaborators and supervisors to contact you.
You can select means of communication (email, cell, pager, etc.) and, for each one, give your contact info (an email address, a phone number etc.).

You can change your password by first entering your current one and then entering (twice) an acceptably secure new password.
Don't forget to press the Apply button for the password change to be effected.

Click on the bar to expand the attachment controls. Use the controls to upload a file or enter a URL and then attach it to the current context.
Assign a type to the attachment, the default being "Reference", to indicate your intent. Attachments of type "Picture" will typically be used as an icon.

As a participant in a community, you may be asked by domain planners to answer surveys in order to help improve the collaboration plan.
You can
* see the surveys you need to complete (and optionally complete them or forward them), * see those you completed (and revise you answers), * and see those you declined (and perhaps change your mind).

You can
* browse and filter the list of all feedback messages you sent to the domain planners for the plan your community has adopted, * expand the conversation with domain planners spawned from feedback, * and add a comment to the conversation.
You can mark feedback as "resolved" once you consider that you have achieved your intended objective.

Organization and their members form collaboration communities, each based on a collaboration plan (a production version).
You can:
* create a new community by first selecting the collaboration plan on which it is based and by pressing the "Start it" button - you will be the founding planner for this community, * view an existing community (select the Go button next to its name in the list of communities).

Authorized participants in a collaboration community can register organizations into the community and assign organizational roles (jobs) to themselves or other users.
If you are a community planner, you can name the community, localize it, update it to a new version of the domain plan, and set collaboration requirements for it. If you are an authorized domain planner, you can access the community's plan.
As a participant, you can access your collaboration checklists, the surveys you take part in, and replies to feedback you provide.
Your Channels user role which is either participant, community planner or administrator.

You can accept to participate in roles that are open to "all" or in roles that have been assigned to you by authorized users.
By check a box next to a role, you accept the role. By unchecking an already checked box, you turn down the role.

Based on your user privileges or current participation, other roles in the community's organization may be available to you.
First select an organization where there are such roles and then select the role. Your selection may be subject to supervisory confirmation.
This a list of roles in which your participation awaits confirmation by supervisors. You can withdraw your request by unchecking the box next to the role.

As a community planner you can define information sharing requirements between organizations.
You can then examine to what extent each requirement can be satisfied by the applicable pairs of organizations, should they follow the plan.
You can add a new requirement definition by pressing the New button in the Definitions tab.
To edit a requirement definition, press on the Edit button next to it in the list of requirements.

If so authorized, you can
* register organizations into the community as "placeholder" organizations defined in the domain plan, * assign users to plan-defined roles in organizations in the community, * confirm the participation of users into roles you supervise, * review participation issues detected by Channels, * resign your status as community planner or bestow it on another user.

If you are a domain planner, you can access the collaboration checklists of all participants; otherwise, you only have access to your own.
By clicking on a participation role, you access the checklists for the role. By clicking on a participant's name, you access the combined checklists for all the roles played by the participant in the community.

Ths report lists the collaboration checklists of a participation given roles in a plan-based community.
The checklists describe
* expected tasks * what events or communications trigger them (if any) * the steps, with or without constraints, by which tasks are executed, including ** actions to be taken ** queries to be made ** self-assigned "research" sub-tasks ** self-assigned follow up tasks
A contacts directory concludes the report.

As a planner, you use Channels to design collaboration plans from which robust collaboration checklists are generated.
A collaboration plan models how various types of organizations share or ought to share information to collaboratively prevent, respond to, or recover from a number of anticipated events that test their missions.
Channels continuously examines these ''collaboration plans'' for gaps and brittleness, and suggests options for remediation.
Channels produces visualizations, analytics and reports that help planners and stakeholders understand and improve complex collaboration plans.
Channels is a ''planning'' tool. It does not manage the ''actual'' sharing of information. It is used to capture and improve the collaboration ''practices'' of organizations and to adaptively produce collaboration checklists.

Channels computes personalized collaboration checklists from a collaboration plan and provides them to plan participants on demand.
As a user's participation in a plan changes, even as events unfold, Channels automatically adapts and updates the user's checklists.

A glossary of collaboration planning terms

A collaboration plan is the combination of * a model of how information is to be acquired and shared so that tasks that achieve organizational goals can be successfully carried out * a plan scope that identifies the plan's participants, namely, people and systems in roles of responsibility within organizations
Applying a scope to a collaboration model produces visualizations, analytics, diagnostics, reports and, crucially, collaboration checklists.
A collaboration plan has one editable development version, zero or one production version (read-only) and any number of retired versions (also read-only).
The development version is released by an administrator. Upon releasing a new version of the plan, a copy of the development version becomes the new production version and the prior production version is retired. Finally, the development version number is incrementd by one.
Anything that contributes to the definition of a collaboration plan, be it a segment, a task, a flow, an entity, information etc. is considered a plan element.

An event is an entity representing a transient change in the world that introduces risks and/or opportunities for organizations.
Risks and events should not be confused. An event can introduce risks to one organization while creating opportunities for another.
From the point of view of the plan, an event is considered an ''incident'' if its occurrence is not planned (an 'outside' event).

A phase is an entity representing a time period relative to the occurrence of events. A phase is either the time before, during or after events.
A collaboration plan can elect to address what happens before, during or after of events, or a combination thereof.
The term ''scenario'' is used in collaboration planning to mean a phase of an event being planned for, possibly occuring in the context of other past or current events.

In Channels, a goal is understood as a ''mission-level'' goal of one or more of the organizations involved in the plan. A goal is either a risk to be mitigated or an opportunity to be seized due to the onset or conclusion of an event.
Goals are achieved by successfully carrying out tasks, or they are automatically achieved when an event terminates.
Mission-level goals are not to be confused with the implied and unstated goals of successfully executing a task or sharing information.

Collaboration plans are composed of one or more or more segments. Each segment addresses a list of organizational goals in one scenario.
No two segments should address identical goals in identical scenarios.
Two segments are connected by the flows that span them and by how a task in one segment can start or end an events, thus initiating the other segment.

Information is shared by collaborating agents (people or systems) via communication channels.
Information is named and can be described by a list of its essential elements.
Information can be constrained to compliance with a named information product that defines a standard list of elements of information.
Each element of information has a name, can be accompanied by handling instructions and be given a secrecy classification.
A task is an action or decision taken, individually or as a team, by assigned agents (people or systems) in order to achieve goals and/or acquire information to share.

Specification of information needed to execute a task, plus requirements on its manner of delivery.
Delivery requirements include * timeliness * transmission media * information format

Specification of information acquired by or for the execution of a task that could be shared with "quality of service" commitments.
Quality of service commitments include * timeliness * transmission media * information format
How agents who carry out a task that ''produces'' information would commit to share that information with agents carrying out a task that ''consumes'' it.
The list of agents assigned to a task because their profiles match the definition of the task.
The commitment by one agent to share information acquired doing a task with another agent who needs it to successfully do some other task.

A problem with the plan that is either detected automatically by Channels or, upon review, by planners. An issue is either one of * validity (something is inherently wrong in the plan) * completeness (something is obviously missing from the plan) * robustness (something is making the plan likely to fail)

You can attach uploaded or linked resources to a collaboration plan or community as a whole, or to any element of a collaboration plan. Attachments can be documents, graphics, videos etc. They can be named and categorized, typically as reference, picture or policy.

An information product is an entity representing a standard bundle of elements of information.
An information product be defined as an extension of another information product to which it adds elements of information.
It is recommended that info needs, capabilities and flows be defined in terms of information products.
An information format is an entity representing a standard format in which information is to be communicated.

An organization is an entity representing an administrative unit (a corporation, an agency, a department, a project team etc.) with a name, a mission, (and possibly a parent organization) and that employs agents in roles of responsibility.

A role is an eneity representing a standard set of responsibilities that one or more organizations can assign to some of its members. A role, such as Manager, is different from a job title, such as Senior VP Sales.

An agent is an entity representing a person or system, or a completely interchangeable group of persons or systems.
An agent can be employed by one or more organizations in titled positions, each specified by a role.
Agent ''types'' are not to be confused with ''roles''. Agent types are used to categorize agents independently of their roles. Examples of agent types are "adult", "trained in CPR", "licensed diver" etc.
A place is an entity used to delimit jurisdictions of agents employed by organizations, to locate where tasks are to be executed, where events are of significance, and where a plan is meant to apply.

A transmission medium is an entity representing the means, technological or not, by which agents communicate.
A transmission medium can be meant for broadcasting (to all), multicasting (to many) or narrowcasting (to one).

A classification system names secrecy classification levels.
Secrecy classifications are used to specify * the clearances of agents * the secrecy of elements of information * the security level of transmission media

A task with the same name as another task overrides it if it assigns a subset of the agents the other task assigns.
An agent is assigned to the overriding task (the more exclusive one), not the overridden task.

A collaboration checklist is a task assigned to an agent, with attendant activity and information sharing steps detailing its execution.
Checklists are triggered by * observation of events, * notifications (from others or from self), * by requests for information (from others or from self), * or by nothing (ongoing tasks)

An entity is a grab bag term for "timeless things and concepts". Entities include * agents * events * information formats * information products * organizations * phases * places * roles * transmission media
Channels distinguishes between "actual" entities and "types" (or categories) of entities. For example, IBM is an organization whereas "Corporation" is a type of organization.
Entities are automatically created when they are first named in the definition of some plan element. No two entities of the same kind can have the same name in a plan.
Entities can be categorized by entity types of the same kind (IBM - an actual organization - is a Corporation -a type of organization - but it can not be a Manager - a role).
Categorized entity types form taxonomies (a Police Chief is a Manager is an Employee).
Events, information formats, information products, phases, roles and transmission media are always types in Channels.

Sharing information can impact the execution of tasks in different ways. It can * trigger the task * terminate the task * be critical (crucial) to the task's success * be useful
When doing failure impact analysis, only flows that trigger, terminate or are crucial to the task's success are considered.

A task is considered useful if it directly achieves a goal or if its failure would prevent another task from achieving a goal.
Only useful tasks are considered when doing failure impact analysis. A useless task is considered an issue by Channels.

Planners can define surveys for various kinds of plan elements (surveys about tasks, about events, about the plan as a whole etc.).
A survey is a questionnaire composed of required and optional questions. Questions can have single or multiple answers and they may allow free commentary.
A survey is applied to one or more plan elements of the appropriate kind (a task survey can be applied to many tasks) and is then sent to one or more users with an optional deadline.
Recipients of surveys can accept and answer the survey and revise their answers at any time. Recipients can decline a survey or forward it to their contacts, who are then automatically registered as Channels users.

A tag is a word or phrase used to tag plan elements in order to informally classify them.
Tags can belong to tag domains. For example, ''esf:transportation'' is the tag ''transportation'' in the tag domain ''esf''.
Tag domains can optionally be predefined by attaching specially formatted text ''tag'' text files to the plan.
A given tag can be applied without constraints to plan elements of different kinds.
One use of tags is to specify information in collaboration requirements.

A collaboration checklist lists the steps required to successfully execute a task.
A step can be either
* some stated activity (other than communicating) * an information request to make, * a notification to send, * sending confirmation of information received, * a self-assigned research sub-task * a self-assigned follow up sub-task
A step may be required or optional. A step may have identify the completion of other steps as pre-requisites.
A step, to be executable, may also require that some stated conditions (an event phase, a goal having been achieved, an information need having been satisfied, the task having failed) be present or absent.
Channels will raise an issue whenever a condition or outcome from the definition of a task is not referenced by at least one step, for example, when a goal achieved by the task is not associated with a step in its checklist.
The communication steps of a checklist are implied by the flows in and out of a task, to and from other agents(requested info to be received and notifications to be sent).
The sub-task steps are implied by flows to self - research sub-tasks are triggering requests to self and followup sub-tasks are triggering notifications to self.
The conditions on executing steps can be the goals achieved and events triggered by the task, or other stated conditions.
The outcomes of a task (events caused or terminated, goals achieved, sharing capabilities acquired) can be associated with the execution of individual steps.

A function specifies the goals to be achieved, the information needed and the information to be acquired by any task implementing the function.
Functions are "entities" and so they can be categorized by other functions. Functions are always entity "types"; there is no such thing as an "actual" function.
A task may or may not declare that it implements a function. If it does, it is expected to conform to the specifications of the function. Issues are raised if the task does not fully do so.

As a domain planner, you can access domain plan editor and a summary report on all issues found in the plan.
As a planner or authorized user you can access the planning surveys you participate in and the feedback you provided.
Documents that have been attached to the plan are directly accessible. New ones can be added.
You can switch to another plan - or another version of this plan - by mousing over the name of the plan in the "breadcrumbs" at the top of the page. A drop-down menu of plans will appear. If this page was accessed from a community, only the versions of the community-adopted plan are accessible.

As a collaboration planner, you use the plan editor to
* define the scope of the plan in terms of risk/opportunity-causing events and of the organizations involved, * compose the plan from segments, each one addressing one phase (before, during, after) of one event, and some of the attendant risks/opportunities * define for each segment the information sharing and tasks required to deal with these risks and opportunities * profile the "entities" (events, phases, organizations, roles etc.) referenced in the collaboration plan * report issues in addition to those automatically detected by Channels * view analytics to better understand the consequences, strengths and weaknesses of the plan

The options are * Planners/Hide planners - Hide or show the planners presence, activities and messages panel * About Plan - Open the plan details panel * About Plan Segment - Open the segment details panel

The options are * Send message - Send a message to planners about this plan as a whole * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste task - Insert the copied task, if any, into the current segment * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this plan as a whole * Add new task - Add a new task to the current segment * New issue - Report a new issue about this plan as a whole * Add new segment - Add a new segment to this plan * Remove this segment - Remove the current segment from this plan

The options are * Index - Open the index of all named elements in this plan * Tags - Open the panel with all the tags used in this plan * Taxonomies - Open the panel showing all entity taxonomies defined in this plan * Who's who - Open the panel listing all agents (people and systems) represented in this plan * All attachments - Open the panel listing all file and Web page attachments in this plan

The options are * Events in Scope - Open the panel with the editable list of all events in the scope of this plan * Goals in Scope - Open the panel showing all goals defined in this plan * Organizations in Scope - Open the panel used to name the organizations (real or placeholders) that are expected to be assigned tasks in this plan * Classification Systems - Open the panel used to define the security classifications used in this plan

The options are * Task Mover - Open the panel used to easily move tasks from the current segment to another * Checklists Map - Open a visualization of how agents and organizations are being assigned to tasks and committed to share information (as reflected in their task checklists) * Plan Evaluation - Open a panel containing metrics of all issues found in this plan * All Issues - Open a panel listing all the issues found in this plan * Plan versions - Open a panel identifying the current version of this plan and allowing planners to vote on moving it to production

The options are * All feedback - Open a panel where all feedback sent about this plan is listed and can be responded to * All surveys - Open a panel from where surveys can be defined, launched and managed

The options are * Send message - Send a message to planners about this segment * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this segment * New issue - Report a new issue about this segment * Move tasks - Open the panel used to easily move tasks from this segment to another

The options are * Details/Hide details - Show or hide the task definition form * Assignments - Show the list of agents in scope that are assignable to the task given its definition * Overrides - Show how this task overrides or is overridden by other tasks (hidden if N/A) * Failure impacts - Open a panel showing the potential impacts of this task failing * Dissemination - Open a panel showing how elements of informations acquired for this tasks disseminate to other tasks * Surveys - Open a panel to launch or access surveys about this task * Agent - Open the profile panel for the agent referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Role - Open the profile panel for the role referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Organization - Open the profile panel for the organization referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Jurisdiction - Open the profile panel for the jurisdiction ( a place) referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Location - Open the profile panel for the location (a place) referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Event - Open the profile panel for the event referenced by the task (hidden if N/A)

The options are * Send message - Send a message to planners about this task * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Copy task - Copy this task * Cut task - Copy and remove this task * Set task from copy - Set the definition of this task from the last copied task * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this task * Paste flow - Add copied info need or capability to this task * New issue - Report a new issue about this task * Implement function - Add goals, information needs and capabilities to implement the task's function * Duplicate task - Add new task as a copy of this one * Satisfy info needs - Create all possible flows that satify this task's info needs, based on existing info capabilities * Disintermediate - Disconnect this task from all flows where it acts as an intermediary

The options are * Details / Hide details - Open or close the definition form * Info product - Open the profile panel for the referenced info product (hidden if N/A) * Elements - Open the elements of information edit panel (hidden if definition form is closed) * Commitments - Open a panel with all computed info sharing commitments (hidden if N/A) * Failure - Open a panel showing the potential impacts of this flow failing (hidden if N/A) * Dissemination - Open a panel showing how elements of informations in this flow disseminate to tasks (hidden if N/A) * Surveys - Open a panel to launch or access surveys about this info need/capability/flow * Send message - Send a message to planners about this info need/capability/flow

The options are * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Copy need/capability/flow - Take a copy * Duplicate need/capability/flow - Add a duplicate need/capability to the task * Remove need/capability/flow - Remove from the task * New issue - Report a new issue about this info need/capability/flow * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this info need/capability/flow * Intermediate flow - Add a "middle man task" between the flow's source and target (hidden if N/A) * Breakup flow - Disconnect the source and target, adding capability and need if implied by the flow (hidden if N/A)

The options are * Show/Hide details - Show or hide the details of this issue reported by a planner * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Remove issue - Remove this issue (hidden if details not shown) * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this reported issue (hidden if details not shown)

The options are * Send message - Send a message to planners about this plan as a whole * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this plan * New issue - Report a new issue about this plan as a whole

The options are * Send message - Send a message to planners about this entity * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this plan * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this entity * New issue - Report a new issue about this entity

The options are * Send message - Send a message * Delete this message - Delete this message I sent (hidden if message was also emailed) * Email this message / Resend email (hidden if message can not be emailed)

You can see the messages you sent to fellow collaboration planners and the messages they sent you.
You can filter out the messages you broadcasted to all planners

You can send a message to one planner or broadcast it to all planners.
The message can be sent internally within Channels or it can also be sent by email. Note that messages sent only internally can be later deleted by the sender.

This shows the list of all domain planners currently working on this domain collaboration plan.
You can also see the list of all authorized planners for this plan, whether they are online or not.

This gives you the list of the most recent changes made to the plan by yourself and other planners. You can hide your own activities.
You can click on the name of the plan element that was changed to quickly navigate to it.

The issues summary report provides metrics on all the issues found in a domain collaboration plan.
The issue metrics are broken down by Robustness issues, Completeness issues and Validity issues.
Name the '''events''' within the scope of the plan and identify those that are ''incidents'' – <small>events that are not caused by planned tasks.</small> –
Note that events can also be named anywhere they are used to define another plan element. When they are, they are automatically added to the scope of the plan.

Name the '''phases''' within the scope of the collaboration plan. Channels will now expect to see at least one segment for each combination of phase and event in scope. The list is part of the plan's ''details''.

item.description:
All segments in the plan are grouped either by event or by phase. They are connected by cross-segment flows and by causation links.
A cross-segment flow is a flow from a task in one segment to a task in another. A causation link is an event caused or terminated by a task in one segment that sets the conditions for another segment.
You can drill down on the cross-segment flows and on the causation links.
From the top action menu, add new segment, then name it and identify the ''scenario' it addresses –<small>the phase of one event, possibly in the context of past or current events</small>.–
You can: * name or rename the segment * give it a description * give it tags * attach documents to it * add a new issue

You can: * identify the phase of the event * identify the event * rate the event severity that qualifies an event for this scenario * specify a context in terms of other events occurring or having occurred

Define a small number of goals the segment is meant to address. For each goal * set the type of goal, * the organization, type or actual, whose goal it is, * the severity/importance of the risk to be mitigated or gain to be achieved. Naming the goal is optional.
All goals defined in all segments of the plan are presented in a table that can be sorted, filtered and paged.
Define a secrecy classification system to be used in setting * an agent's clearances, * the security of a transmission medium, * the classification level of shared elements of information.

Information flow maps depict how information is consumed and produced by tasks and to what effects.
Represented in a flow map are * Events which initiations or terminations trigger tasks * Event initiated or terminated by tasks * Goals (risks or opportunities) achieved by tasks * Tasks * The information needs and capabilities of tasks * Information sharing flows connecting tasks
Flow maps can be maximized, reduced-to-fit, and simplified by hiding goals, and info needs and capabilities.
A task is brought into focus for editing by clicking on it in the flow map. Flows can also be opened for editing by clicking on them in the flow map.

Add new task to a segment by clicking ''ADD'' in the Task panel or by selecting ''add new task'' from the top Actions menu. The newly created task is intially empty and presented as ''someone doing something''.

Define a task by * naming it * identifying the function it implements * identifying where it is to be executed * profiling who is to be assigned to it * what goals it directly achieves * and more Note that as little and as much as wanted can be put into a task's definition.

Add an '''information need''' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Receives panel. An info need specifies information that agents assigned to the task need to receive to * trigger the task * enable it to succeed (critical) * terminate the task (useful) * or improve its execution

Add an ''informatio capability'' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Sends panel. An info capability specifies info agents assigned to a task expect to acquire and be able to share with others.

Specify an information need, capability or sharing by * naming the information * requiring the information to be compliant with a named information product * listing its elements * indicating whether it is ''pushed'' (a notification) or ''pulled' (a requested answer) * whether the need, capability or sharing is private or can be made known to parties other than those who need, can share, share or receive the information. * setting restrictions based on the relationships (employment, location, authority, identity) between sources and targets * the communication channels to use, each including transmission medium and, optionally, a required format * timeliness constraints * and more

You can list the essential elements of information of an information need, capability or flow, and set their properties.
The properties of an element of information are * its name * the question it answers * its security classification * its handling instructions * if produced, how it transforms , if at all, received elements * if defining an info need, whether its delivery is subject to timeliness constraints

An information sharing flow connect a tasks that ''produces'' information with a tasks that ''consumes'' it. It is equivalent to connecting an info capability of a task with the info need of another.
A sharing flow is created by connecting an info need or a capability to a task. The flow appears in the ''Receives'' of the consuming task and in the ''Sends'' of the producing task.
Tasks in different segments can only be connected via their respective, defined info need and info capability.
The list of tasks that either override this task or are overridden by it.

A checklist comes pre-populated with steps representing the requested information to be received, the notifications to be sent, the research and follow-up sub-tasks that are defined for the task as flows.
These communication steps can not be removed from the checklist. Action steps, representing simple activities requiring no communication or new information, can be added and removed.
A step can be given: * Prerequisite steps - steps the step must come "after" * Conditions that must be present for the step to be taken ("if") * Conditions that must be absent for the step to be taken ("unless") * Outcomes from the execution of a step
Action steps (not communication steps) can be marked as "required", else they are optional. Communication and sub-task steps are marked as required if they are notifications or follow-ups.
Conditions applicable on steps are either: * Goals achieved by the task * Events triggered or terminated by the task * Information needs of the task * The task having failed (a non-optional condition for "on-failure notification steps) * Conditions ''local'' to the execution of the task added to the checklist - they can also be removed
Outcomes of a steps can be: * Goals, if any, achieved by the task * Events, if any, caused or terminated by the task * Sharing capabilities acquired for or from successfully executing the task
A checklist must be confirmed to be deployed to participants as such. Any change to the implied communication steps or to the action steps requires a re-confirmation.
A process flow describing the execution of the checklist is accessed by clicking on the flow icon next to the name of the task.

The checklist flow diagram depicts how the steps in the checklist are to be executed.
The green dot represents start of execution and the red dot its end. Execution is from left to right.
Steps that can be executed in parallel are depicted in parallel. Steps that must precede one another are depicted in sequences.
Steps that are executed conditionally are preceded by ''if'' and/or ''unless'' conditions. If there is more than one condition constraining a step, the conditions precede the step in a sequence.
The outcomes of steps are shown linked to the steps.

Define an event (always a type, never an actual event) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with event types * locating where it would happen * stating whether the event can terminate on its own * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All events are listed in '''All events'''
Events can be found by name in the plan's index.
Define a phase (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * specifying if it is a pre-, co- or post-event phase * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All phases are listed in the plan's '''details'''.
Phases can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define an actual or type of organization by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with organization types * If an actual organization, by ** naming the parent organization ** listing the agents it employs, with titles and roles, and optionally jurisdictions and supervisors Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Define a role (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Roles can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define an actual or type of agent by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with agent types * If an actual agent, by ** declaring it a person or system ** setting clearances, languages, availability ** setting constraints on users participating as this agent * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Agents can be found in the plan's ''who's who''.
Agents can also be found by name in the plan's index.

Define an actual or type of place by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with place types (such as 'city', 'building' etc.) * if an actual place, by ** naming what place it is within ** giving a street address and postal code ** identifying its geographical area * if a type of place, by ** setting the place (type or actual) it must be in ** the place it must contain * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Places can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define a transmission medium (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * stating whether it is unicast, multicast or broadcast * naming the other media this one can delegate to * naming its level of security * giving the pattern the media's ''addresses'' must conform to * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Transmission media can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define an information product (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * defining the elements of information flows standardized to this information product require * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Information products can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define an information format (always a type) that can qualify communication channels by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Information formats can be found by name in the plan's index.

Define a function that tasks can implement.
A function can be: * named * described * categorized by other (more generic) functions
A function defines the kinds of goals, if any, a task implementing it is expected to achieve, as well as the information needs and information capabilities that such a task is expected to have in order to conform to the function.
The goals specified by a function are goal categories plus whether they are risks to be mitigated or gaines to be made.
The information needs and capabilities specified by the function are named, optionally point to an information product, and define function-specific elements of information.
When a function is categorized by other functions, it adds to the goals, information needs and capabilitites that the categorizing functions define.
Functions can be found by name in the plan's index.

A collaboration plan determines how agents must commit to share information with one another.
Commitment networks depict these info sharing commitment relationships between agents either directly or aggregated by role or organization.
You can drill down on each commitment relationship to see the info sharing commitments it summarizes.
You can see what organizations have agents assigned to a segment's task and how these organizations are linked by info sharing commitments.
You can see the different ways in which this entity is involved in the plan, and then drill down.

Issues may have been detected or reported about this entity's profile. You can include issues about other plan elements that relate to the entity. You can also filter out issues that have been waived by planners (the default).
You can browse a paginated table of these issues, filter them, sort them and drill down on them.
To create or view an existing survey about the resolution of this issue, click on the survey icon.
You can visualize where, according to plan, individual elements of informations comsumed by a task would come from, and where elements of information produced by a task would end up.

You can visualize how the failure of a task or of a flow can cause the cascading failures of useful tasks, thus jeopardizing the achiement of organizational goals.
Only useful tasks and critical flows are considered when doing failure impact analysis.

Channels automatically detected issues about this plan element. You or other planners may also have reported issues about it.
All issues about the plan element are listed. The planner-reported issues can be opened up to edit their names, description, severity and remediation options. When editing remediation options, start each one on a new line.
Some issues detected by Channels can be waived (marked as false positives).
You can report a new issue by pressing the New button and then editing the issue. When describing remediation options, start each one on a new line.
You can automatically create a survey about remediating an issue by pressing on the ''Create survey'' button. If a survey was already created, you can view it by pressing the the ''View survey'' button.

The current production and development versions for this plan are identified.
You can vote to move the current development version of this in production if you believe it is ready. You can see the votes of other planners and send them messages. Note that only an administrator can actually put the current development version into production.

The plan evaluation gives an accounting of the issues found in this plan. The metrics are expressed in terms of * the three main types of issues (robustness, completeness, validity) * their severity * whether they were waived or not * and how many different kinds of issues were found
All issues found in the plan are listed in a paged table. You can sort them, filter them, search on their names and drill down on them.
An obvious way of improving a collaboration plan is to resolve issues detected by Channels and by planners. The 'All issues" table aggregates all individual issues found in a plan.
Metrics on all issues found in a plan provide a sense of the current quality of the collaboration plan.
If the resolution of an issue is not self-evident and requires input from stakeholders, a survey (with questionnaire) can be created about resolving the issue.
When too many tasks are added to a segment, the segment becomes difficult to manage. To shrink a bloated segment, a new segment is usually created and tasks are moved to it.

Collaboration checklists are computed by assigning agents to tasks and by deriving information sharing commitments from the flows connecting assigned tasks.
A key concern is making sure that the right agents get assigned to the right tasks, and that only the right agents that are assigned to the tasks on each side of a flow become parties to sharing commitments.
Which agents are assigned to a task is determined by * how a task specifies the agents assignable to it * what agents are in the plan's environments and how they are profiled * how the agents are employed (role, jurisdiction, organization) * how the taxonomies of role, agent, organization etc. are defined

Exactly what sharing commitments are generated for a flow depends on * what agents are assigned to the producing task and consuming task connected by the flow * what restrictions are put on pairing agents into commitments (the committer and beneficiary must be in the same organization etc.) * whether an overriding flow prohibits a pairing of agents

Entities (i.e. roles, agents, organizations, places, events etc.) can be categorized. Agents are categorized by agent types, organization by organization types, events by other events (events are always types) etc.
How entities are categorized largely determine the meaning of the tasks, flows, employments etc. that are defined in terms of these entities.
The meaning of a plan boils down to the task assignments and consequent sharing commitments (checklists) that are implied by the collaboration plan.
Even a small change to the taxonomy (a.k.a. typology) or roles, for example, can cause widespread changes to the checklists computed from a plan, and thus its meaning.
Taxonomies are defined implictly by categorizing individual entities. The best way to verify that taxonomies are correct is to visualize them.

A ''flow map'' shows tasks connected by flows where each flow can imply a potentially large number of sharing commitments. The ''checklists map'' makes it easy to see if the sharing commitments generated from the plan are the intended ones.
The map is focused on one agent or one organization (as an aggregate of agents). It shows the commitments that involved that egent or organizations.
The other parties to the commitments can be aggregated by role, organization type or not at all.
Clicking on an assigned task navigates to the task's definition and opens the checklist flow diagram for this task.

All the checklists (one for each task in the plan) are listed, to be sorted on the task names, segment names and their confirmation status.
Checklists can be filtered to see only the ones confirmed or not confirmed, or to see only the checklists in a given segment.
Clicking on the name of a tasks or a segment, takes you to it.

You can enlist the help of stakeholders via surveys. A survey is a questionnaire about elements of the plan or the plan as a whole.
You compose questionnaires by adding, ordering, editing etc. statements and questions. Questions can be marked as required or optional.
A questionnaire applies to the plan as a whole or to one kind of plan element (plan questionnaire, task questionnaires, event questionnaires etc.)
Questionnaires can be activated and deactivated. They can be extended while they are being used in surveys.
A survey is launched on the plan or on a plan element by applying a questionnaire to it.

script.action: View launched and launch-able surveys on a task

item.description: Once a survey is launched, it can be managed by * inviting users to participate * looking at the answers from survey participants * deactivating or reactivating the survey * editing the survey's questionnaire

Surveys can be launched on an issue that was detected. The questionnaire is automatically generated based on the remediation options.
The questionnaire can be modified and extended while the survey is ongoing.
An issue remediation survey is automatically deactivated when the issue disappears.
Note that the issue remediation questionnaires are by default not shown in the list of all questionnaires; a checkbox must be checked to see them.

Once a survey is launched, users can be invited to participate in it. Users can be given a deadline to answer all of the survey's required questions.
After the deadline has passed, the survey is considered late. Late participants can be ''nagged'' (nags are sent by email).
A participant can *accept the invitation by answering questions, *decline the invitation *forward the survey to others (if it was marked as forwardable by planners).
Note that anyone who is forwarded a survey and who is not yet a user of Channels is automatically given a login, password and limited access to the plan as a participant.

topic.name: Lookup the results of a survey

item.description:
As participants in a survey answer the questionnaire, results are compiled and made available to all planners.
Results can be viewed by opening the survey and selecting the Results tabs.

Users can ask questions, report problems and make suggestions via a feedback widget that appears in their home page, their checklists etc.
You can see this feedback and reply to it. The user can then reply back etc. or mark the question, problem or suggestion as resolved.

Every element of a plan that has a name can be found from the index.
The index can be filtered by kind of element (role, agent, event etc.), by tags, and by partial name.

Every employement of every agent is aggregated in the ''who's who'' table.
The table can be indexed by the name of the agent or by attributes of employment (organization, role, location of employer).

Documents and Web pages of various types (policy, reference, picture etc.) can be attached to the plan and any element in it.
A table with all attachments in the plan can be found in the plan's ''attachments''.

The plan and every element in it can be tagged.
The list of all tags used in the plan can be looked up to see what has been marked by any given tag.

The entity types used to categorize roles, agents, organizations, places, events etc. (entities) can themselves be categorized to create taxonomies.
Changes to a taxonomy can have profound impacts on the collaboration checklists that are generated by the plan.
Taxonomies can be visualized to verify that they are correct.

Whenever a plan element is referenced by name in the definition of another, there will also be a link to get to the referenced element's definition.
Also, most forms used to define an element of the plan contain a table listing and linking to all other elements that reference it in their definitions.
For example, at the bottom of in the profile of a role is an index of all other plan elements that reference the role or that match the role.

script.action: Open the a role profile to see its references

item.description: You can report an issue about the current context by pressing the New button, and then * providing a brief description of the issue * giving the type of issue (validity, completeness or robustness) * optionally tagging the issue * rating the severity of the issue * giving options for its remediation (start each option on a new line)

As an administrator, you manage plans and users for a Channels server.
Plan management consists of:
* Creating a new plan with a unique resource identifier (URI) * Deleting a plan - permitted only if not yet adopted by a community * Putting the current development version of a plan into production * Naming the owner of the plan * Changing the default email addresses at which participant or planner feedback is sent
User management consists of:
* Adding a new user with a unique username - be aware that users can not be deleted, only disabled * Giving a user a full name, email address and password - the user can later modify all of these * Making the user as an admin * Disabling the user - this can be later reversed * Giving the user planner vs guest (view-only) status for specific plans.
Make sure to press the Apply button for changes to take effect.
